text.p: Bonds recovered from their lows after the market concluded that higher than expected price rises in May would not break the downward trend in inflation.
Traders said that there was even room for the 10-year spread with the cash Bund to narrow slightly on Wednesday, aided by the renewed optimism over monetary union.

Analysts do not expect the Bank of Portugal to cut official interest rates on Wednesday for the start of a new commercial bank reserve period and therefore there is unlikely to be any steepening of the yield curve.

"After the selling on the inflation, the market recovered on the notion the rise was one-off and the downtrend remains in tact," said one trader. Year-on-year inflation was 2.1 percent against forecasts for between 1.4 and April's 1.8 percent.
"The inflation was bad due to potatoes and pork meat but the other sectors evolved well," said one broker.

"Convergence for the single currency will give a boost to the peripheries tomorrow and the spread could go towards 60 basis points," he added. The two year bond closed with a yield of 5.23 percent, up from 5.15 percent before news of the inflation figure and 5.21 percent at Monday's close.
